children.name: To deliberately not go to work
skive
children.definition: /skive off/ bunk off/skaɪv, ˌskaɪv ˈɒf, ˌbʌŋk ˈɒf/  Britishinformalto deliberately not go to work when you should be there:
examples: trốn việc
▪ He says that he was so ill he had to be sent home from school. I bet he’s skiving.
▪ Have you been skiving off again? You’ll get caught one of these days.
▪ We were bunking off one day, and playing down by the canal.
skive/skaɪv/ [intransitive verb] British informal to not do the work that you should be doing, or to be away from your place of workwithout a good reason:
trốn việc
▪ She says she’s been ill for the past week, but I think she’s just skiving.
skive offnot be at your place of work
▪ Harry’s going to get into trouble if he keeps skiving off on Friday afternoons.
skiver[countable noun]
▪ Everyone knew that Ned was the biggest skiver in the class.
